description: Jerry Harris, who shot to reality-TV fame in the Netflix show Cheer, pleaded guilty on Thursday to federal charges related to soliciting child sexual abuse imagery and illegal sexual conduct with a minor, reversing his earlier plea.

title: First Justice Department Memo on Killing Anwar Al-Awlaki
description: The Obama administration on Aug. 15, 2014, released the first Justice Department Office of Legal Counsel memo on killing Anwar Al Awlaki, an American citizen deemed a terrorist, without a trial. The once-secret February 2010 memo would later be replaced by a lengthier version signed in July 2010. Both memos were made public, in redacted form, following Freedom of Information Act lawsuits by the New York Times and the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: Patricia Moreno, Spiritual Fitness Leader, Dies at 57
description: Patricia Moreno, who injected a dose of spirituality into the world of fitness and created a popular exercise program called intenSati, which became a staple at some Equinox gyms and a presence on YouTube, died on Jan. 22 at her home in Los Angeles. She was 57.

title: The Ottawa Trucker Protests Are a Test of Democracy
description: By the standards of mass protests around the world, the Freedom Convoy snarling Downtown Ottawa ranks as a nuisance. The number of protesters, about 8,000 at their peak, is modest; there have been no serious injuries or altercations, the truckers stopped blaring their horns after residents got a temporary court injunction against them, and most Canadians support neither the truckers nor their cause. Yet whats happening in Canada deserves close attention in the United States and across the world.

title: Film Club: Almost Famous: The Queen of Basketball
description: The Queen of Basketball is a 22-minute Oscar-nominated film that touches on themes of sports, fame and the barriers faced by women athletes. It tells the story of Lusia Lucy Harris Stewart, one of womens basketballs most accomplished players, who died in January 2022. She was a pioneer in the sport, scoring the first basket in womens Olympic history and becoming the first and only woman officially drafted by the N.B.A. And while she was one of the first two women inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame, she has remained largely unknown, even among basketball enthusiasts.

title: In a First, Fordham Will be Led by a Woman, Not a Catholic Priest
description: Fordham University, one of the most prominent Jesuit universities in the United States, announced its new president on Thursday, unveiling a choice that breaks with tradition in two significant ways: For the first time in its nearly 200-year history, the school will be led by a laywoman instead of a priest.

title: With Buildup on Land and Sea, Russia Closes in on Ukraine
description: MOSCOW  Thousands of Russian troops on Thursday began 10 days of exercises in Belarus, and Ukraine warned of upcoming Russian naval drills so extensive they would block shipping lanes, as the Kremlin continued to tighten its military vise on Ukraine.

title: Why Are American Troops Still in Iraq?
description: U.S. troops in Iraq quietly thwarted two separate drone attacks on bases hosting American soldiers in the first week of 2022. The attacks, attributed to Iraqi Shiite militias, are no surprise: Americas presence in Iraq is increasingly unwelcome. More attacks are bound to come as long as the Biden administration decides to keep forces there. With each passing day, the risk of a deadly attack increases.

title: Justice Department Memo Approving Targeted Killing of Anwar Al-Awlaki
description: Following Freedom of Information Act lawsuits, the Obama administration released a 2010 Justice Department memo signing off on killing Anwar Al-Awlaki, an American citizen, without a trial.

title: Armed Nationalists in Ukraine Pose a Threat Not Just to Russia
description: KYIV, Ukraine  The Ukrainian political activist and militia member sat before his partys flag leaving little doubt about his readiness for action. The flag depicted two axes crossed against a field of red.

title: Protesters Opposing Covid Vaccine Pass Head to Paris
description: Truckers and drivers departed from across France with the goal of converging as a convoy in Paris to protest the countrys vaccination pass program. The effort was directly inspired by Canadas trucker-led movement.

title: Bridge Blockade Must Come to an End, Windsor Mayor Says
description: Drew Dilkens, the mayor of Windsor, Ontario, said the City Council had authorized a superior court injunction to be sought in an effort to end the blockade and have protesters removed if necessary.

title: California sues Tesla, saying the company permitted racial discrimination at its factory.
description: A California state agency is suing Tesla, accusing it of allowing racial discrimination and harassment to flourish at its San Francisco Bay Area factory in a lawsuit that was made public on Thursday.

title: Puerto Rico Teachers Lead Push for Higher Pay for Public Workers
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.  In Puerto Rico, the base pay for public-school teachers is $1,750 a month  a figure that has not increased in 13 years and has forced Jessica Coln Cartagena, a special-education teacher, to tutor students and run a catering business with her husband to make ends meet.

title: John Wesley, an Artist Who Couldnt Be Pinned Down, Dies at 93
description: John Wesley, a painter of flat, cartoonish figures that seemed to spring not from the well of Pop Art but from some deeper, stranger reservoir of the American unconscious inhabited by floating babies, rubbery nudes and the hapless comic-strip husband Dagwood Bumstead, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.

title: Libya Slides Deeper Into Chaos as Parliament Picks New Government
description: CAIRO  Libya hurtled deeper into political chaos on Thursday when its Parliament voted to install a new interim government over the objections of the current prime minister.

title: What Students Are Saying About Black History, Food-Centric Traditions and Wordle
description: This week on The Learning Network, one of our writing prompts asked teenagers to tell us what they have learned about Black history at home or in school. We also wanted to know if they celebrate any special cultural or holiday traditions that involve food, and we asked them to weigh in on the meteoric rise of the game Wordle.

title: New satellite images show more Russian forces massing on three sides of Ukraine.
description: Satellite images collected on Wednesday and Thursday reveal new deployment and positioning of Russian military equipment and troops in multiple locations around Ukraine, including Crimea, western Russia and Belarus, adding to an already ominous buildup that has fueled invasion fears.

title: NASA-Funded Satellites Lost in Setback for Astra, a Small Rocket Launch Start-Up
description: Four tiny NASA-funded satellites were lost on their way to space on Thursday after launching atop a rocket built by Astra Space, a small, publicly traded rocket start-up based in Alameda, Calif.

title: M.L.B. Commissioner: Missing Games Would Be Disastrous
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  With spring training slated to start in less than a week, and no new labor deal in place with the players, Major League Baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said that there were no changes to the baseball calendar yet and that he was optimistic that an agreement would be struck in time to begin the regular season as scheduled on March 31.

title: A One-Legged Man Bathing on a Rooftop in Syria? Must Be ISIS Leader.
description: WASHINGTON  A vital clue in the two-year manhunt for the Islamic States elusive leader fell into place last fall when a U.S. spy drone spotted a bearded man bathing atop a three-story building in northwest Syria. The man was missing his right leg.

title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Smiling FriendsWhen to watch: Now, on HBO Max.

title: Nearly 3,000 N.Y.C. Workers Have a Day to Get Vaccinated or Be Fired
description: Hundreds of municipal workers marched across the Brooklyn Bridge this week, chanting in unison for New York City to end its vaccine mandate, and carrying signs that said Fire Fauci and Unvaccinated Lives Matter.

title: F.D.A. Panel Rejects Lillys Cancer Drug Tested Only in China
description: An advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration overwhelmingly voted on Thursday against recommending agency approval of a lung cancer drug that was tested only in China and sold there.

title: Nets James Harden Traded to Sixers for Ben Simmons
description: The Nets traded James Harden, a former Most Valuable Player Award winner, to the Philadelphia 76ers on Thursday for a package centered on Ben Simmons, the three-time All-Star point guard who has not played this season for personal reasons.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: The School Unmasking Debate
description: Now that Democratic states like Connecticut, Massachusetts and New Jersey are lifting their mandates, schools in liberal-leaning communities are being forced to decide: When should the masks come off?

title: Trump, Inflation, Olympics: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Joe Burrows Last Playoff Loss Was in High School. He Still Thinks About It.
description: [Read how the Los Angeles Rams won the Super Bowl.]

title: Canadian Trucker Protests Snarl an Already Hobbled Auto Industry
description: After two years of the pandemic, semiconductor shortages and supply chain chaos, it seemed as if nothing else could go wrong for the auto industry and the millions of people it employs. But then came thousands of truckers who, angry about vaccine mandates, have been blocking major border crossings between Canada and the United States.

title: Is the Web3 Gold Rush the Beginning of a New Internet or a Scam?
description: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays. Debatable will be off on Feb. 15 and will return on Feb. 17.

title: Trucker Protests in Canada: What You Need to Know
description: For weeks, Canadian protesters fighting vaccine requirements have paralyzed Ottawa and key border crossings, inspired demonstrations around the globe and injected political instability into the stunned top of Canadian government.

title: Dont Write It Off: Advice From Brain Injury Experts After Bob Sagets Death
description: It appeared to be an ordinary fall: Bob Saget, the actor and comedian, knocked his head on something and, perhaps thinking nothing of it, went to sleep, his family said on Wednesday.

title: Opening a Restaurant in Miami? Invoking Cuban Communism Might Backfire.
description: MIAMI  A Manhattan restaurant planning an expansion to Miami has drawn the ire of some Cuban Americans after its use of Communist lore was pointed out on social media.

title: The N.F.L.s About-Face on Sports Gambling
description: [Read how the Los Angeles Rams won the Super Bowl.]

title: Astra Rocket Launch Fails to Reach Orbit
description: Minutes after the rockets launch, as its second stage booster was supposed to break off for its trip deeper into orbit, onboard cameras showed the booster tumbling out of control.

title: Mikaela Shiffrin finishes her first race of these Olympics, the super-G.
description: It has been a long time since a ninth place finish felt like a triumph for Mikaela Shiffrin, but there she was, at the finish area of the super-G Friday afternoon, speaking as though she had truly won something.

title: Shaun White, on his farewell tour, prepares for his final runs.
description: Shaun White was at the bottom of the halfpipe, chatty and relieved, just as the sun was sinking. He was talking about making it through to another Winter Olympics final, two days away, and maybe, just maybe, finishing his career, at 35, with another gold medal.

title: 2 Men Sentenced in Sex-Trafficking Ring That Preyed on Teenage Girls
description: Delia was 13 when she started dating Francisco Melendez-Perez, a 16-year-old she met in a park in Mexico. She thought that he was handsome and nice, and that he would bring stability and love to her life.

title: Vacancies in Top Health and Science Jobs May Threaten Bidens Agenda
description: WASHINGTON  President Biden, who came into office vowing to reinvigorate our national science and technology strategy, is now facing a leadership vacuum that may threaten his ambitious research agenda, which stretches well beyond fighting the coronavirus pandemic.

title: U.S. prime-time broadcast coverage on Thursday includes snowboarding halfpipe and super-G.
description: The U.S. broadcast coverage of the 2022 Winter Games continues on Thursday with medal events in snowboarding halfpipe and Alpine skiing super-G, as the hockey and curling competitions advance and skeleton begins. All times are Eastern.

title: Explaining the Claim That the Biden Administration Is Funding Crack Pipes
description: WASHINGTON  Republican lawmakers and conservative news outlets have accused the Biden administration of planning to give out pipes for smoking crack cocaine.

title: Biden Predicts His Supreme Court Nominee Will Get Republican Support
description: WASHINGTON  President Biden said on Thursday that he had thoroughly vetted four potential Supreme Court nominees so far, all of whom he believes could draw the support of Republican senators during the nomination process.

title: Where New Yorks Pasta Lovers Go to Stock Their Cupboards
description: In this series for T, the author Reggie Nadelson revisits New York institutions that have defined cool for decades, from time-honored restaurants to unsung dives.

title: What the Beatles Tell Us About Fame
description: Lets say youre a musician, artist or actor with dreams of making it big. How do you do that?

title: The Pandemic Culls the Big Tech Herd
description: It feels like another turbulent time in tech, another paradigm shift, like what happened with the move to mobile. In this case, it is a move away from the internet as we know it (Web2)  a soft-touch regulatory environment  to whats being called Web3, where actual guardrails might be erected.

title: How Republicans Saw Inflation Coming
description: If Democrats lose control of Congress in November, it seems safe to say that inflation will be a major reason for their defeat.

title: A 1,500-Year-Old Riddle Solved: Yes, It Was a Terra-Cotta Porta-Potty
description: Archaeologists working at ancient Roman sites commonly find ceramics, but it is not always easy to know what these objects were used for. Wine storage? Food transportation? Tableware? Or were they purely decorative? Experts often disagree. But now a team of researchers working at a Roman site that dates from about 450 to 500 A.D. have definitive proof that one of the pots they found was a portable toilet.

title: Bidens Hidden Health Care Triumph
description: A Republican member of Congress said something epically stupid the other day.

title: The Slippery Science of Skeleton
description: Many Winter Olympic sports have ancient origins, dating to times when humans invented new ways of getting around in the harsh, white wilderness. Skiing may have first emerged 10,000 years ago in Altay, China, and the Indigenous Smi word for skiing (uoigat) is estimated to be 6,000 to 8,000 years old. Thousands of years ago in Northern Europe, people strapped animal bones to their feet to skate around on ice. And the First Peoples in Canada used toboggans to transport goods.

title: Panel Approves Transfer of Saudi Engineer From Guantnamo Bay
description: WASHINGTON  A U.S. government review panel on Thursday approved the release with security guarantees of a Saudi prisoner at Guantnamo Bay who was captured in Pakistan and held as a suspected bomb maker.

title: Republicans Who Railed About Clinton Emails Are Quiet on Trumps Records
description: Donald J. Trump once thundered that the questions surrounding Hillary Clintons use of a private email server were bigger than Watergate. On his 2016 presidential campaign, where are her emails? became a Republican rallying cry that was soon replaced with an even more threatening demand: Lock her up.

title: Paranoia About #MeToo Overreach at Harvard
description: Thirty-eight of Harvards leading lights, people who are among the most accomplished and admired intellectuals in the world, last week signed an open letter expressing their concern that a colleague, the renowned anthropologist John Comaroff, had been punished for violating the schools sexual and professional conduct policies. Among them was the African-American studies professor, critic and filmmaker Henry Louis Gates Jr., the historian and New Yorker writer Jill Lepore, the medical anthropologist and physician Paul Farmer and the postcolonial theorist Homi K. Bhabha.

title: What to Know About the KF94 Mask
description: Even as mask mandates begin to lift across the country, many people still need high-quality masks for air travel, shopping and visiting the doctor. One of the best options is the KF94 from South Korea.

title: Shaun White Finds the Glory in Falling Short
description: ZHANGJIAKOU, China  It all came to an end here, on a tilted chute of ice on an unnamed mountain in China, and the only surprise was that 35-year-old Shaun White did not have one more trick in him. He had made a career of such things.

title: Canada Protests Unprecedented, Ottawa Police Say
description: Peter Sloly, Ottawas police chief, said the protesters were increasingly using sophisticated tactics to target law-enforcement operations, such as flooding emergency lines with fake 911 calls, many originating from the United States.

title: Shaun White isnt the only American snowboarding for gold.
description: All eyes may be on Shaun Whites final runs on Thursday, but two other Americans are hoping to make it to the winners podium.

title: Harper Lee Estate Told to Pay $2.5 Million in Dispute Over Mockingbird Plays
description: An arbitrator has ordered the estate of the writer Harper Lee to pay more than $2.5 million in damages and fees to Dramatic Publishing, a theatrical publishing company that has licensed a stage adaptation of To Kill a Mockingbird for decades.

title: Who is Valentino Guseli?
description: Valentino Guseli, a 16-year-old from Australia, began to make a name for himself when he broke the world record for the highest vertical last year at his first World Cup contest.

title: Who is Scotty James?
description: Four years ago, Scotty James of Australia won the bronze medal in the mens halfpipe at the Pyeongchang Games in South Korea, becoming Australias first male snowboarder to win an Olympic medal. Now, James is looking to upgrade his title, and his medal, by taking home the gold.

title: Who is Ayumu Hirano?
description: After taking home silver in the mens halfpipe at the last two Winter Olympics, Ayumu Hirano of Japan is a favorite heading into the finals and a snowboarder to watch in the race for gold.

title: Tall Girl 2 Review: She Stoops
description: Jodi Kreyman (Ava Michelle) is a high-school student who towers above her peers at nearly 6-foot-2 and wears size 13 sneakers  mens size 13, that is. This insecure beanstalk had semi-fertile grounds for angst in the romantic comedy Tall Girl (2019), which culminated with Jodi barging onto her homecoming stage in five-inch heels to deliver a defiant sermon about self-acceptance. Tall Girl 2, an inessential sequel by the director Emily Ting and the returning screenwriter Sam Wolfson, picks up a semester later, in springtime, with Jodi adjusting to shocking, newfound popularity. The wallflower is now circled by four male suitors: her former tormentor (Rico Paris); a theater kid (Jan Luis Castellanos) who recites Jodis big speech as an actors monologue; a Swedish exchange student hunk (Luke Eisner) who dinged her pride in the first film; and her steady, short king Jack Dunkleman (Griffin Gluck), who whips up a candlelit turducken dinner for their three-month anniversary.

title: C.I.A. Is Collecting in Bulk Certain Data Affecting Americans, Senators Warn
description: WASHINGTON  The Central Intelligence Agency has for years been collecting in bulk, without a warrant, some kind of data that can affect Americans privacy, according to a newly declassified letter by two senators.

title: Biden Warns U.S. Wont Send Troops to Rescue Americans in Ukraine
description: WASHINGTON  President Biden on Thursday warned Americans to leave Ukraine, saying that U.S. troops would not be dispatched to retrieve them should Russia invade.

title: Hacker Who Sold Pirated Video Games Gets More Than 3 Years in Prison
description: A video game hacker and prominent member of a group that sold pirated video games, costing Nintendo and other companies more than $65 million, was sentenced in federal court in Washington State on Thursday to 40 months in prison, prosecutors said.

title: What Friendly Opponents May Do
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  Before we talk about Trenton Charlsons very entertaining puzzle, I just wanted to mention that applications are now being accepted for the first New York Times Diverse Crossword Constructor Fellowship.

title: Variety: Acrostic
description: ACROSTIC  Let this puzzle serve as a reminder that its not too late to order your chocolates and flowers for Presidents Day, which falls on Feb. 21 this year, a day before George Washingtons actual birthday. (Hell be 290 years old.) As a committed non scholar of the founders, I have scant knowledge of Washington, mostly pertaining to the cherry tree and his wooden teeth, both of which are fallacies. Todays passage concerns the teeth and their actual composition.

title: Praise for Jan. 6 Costs Virginia Deputy Attorney General Her Job
description: A recently appointed Virginia deputy attorney general resigned on Thursday after a report that she had praised the Jan. 6 rioters on Facebook and claimed that President Donald J. Trump had won the 2020 election.

title: Review: Even With Hugh Jackman, The Music Man Goes Flat
description: There comes a moment in the latest Broadway production of Meredith Willsons The Music Man when high spirits, terrific dancing and big stars align in an extended marvel of showbiz salesmanship.

title: He Became an Olympic Sensation, Without a Shirt and Without Competing
Star Russian Figure Skater Tested Positive for Banned Drug
description: Update: Kamila Valievas sample had three substances sometimes used to help the heart.

title: Aaron Rodgers Wins Fourth N.F.L. M.V.P. Award
description: [Read how the Los Angeles Rams won the Super Bowl.]

title: How much is a gold medal actually worth?
description: The medal counts are ticking up, with dozens of golds awarded so far to countries including Slovenia, New Zealand, Germany and China.

title: The Chinese mens hockey team has an international cast.
description: The descendants of some of the many Chinese people who emigrated to North America in the 19th century are back in China, playing hockey for the host team at the Beijing Olympics.

title: In Their Different Cultures, They Found Common Denominators
description: By the time Sneha Medappa Maruvanda met Dr. Mark Ross Edelstein in person, she feared they might not have anything left to say to each other.

title: He Caught Her Attention at the Community Center
description: Caroline Combs used to call John Dansby the hot nurse.

title: On the Eve of Lockdown, a Jam-Packed First Date
description: On Jan. 28, 2020, Sharon Deckey Mussalli was scrolling through Instagram when she came upon a black-and-white photo of Shaun Robert Jenkins, a senior manager of training at Tone House, a trendy gym in New York City.

title: Roller-Skating Straight to His Heart, on Pink Wheels
description: In September 2015, Henderson Moore Blumer could sense the panic of fellow art student Suzanne Zoe Joskow.

title: A Muslim Dating App Powered Their Connection
description: When Jafreen Momtaj Uddin and Shakil Sarfaroz Rabbi matched on Salams, a Muslim dating app, in June 2021, they immediately began a two-hour online conversation that Ms. Uddin described as extremely comfortable.

title: Finding Each Other in the Place They Had Always Been
description: When Denise Parnell and Whitney Hardy first encountered each other in 2009, it was on a blind date  one that Ms. Parnell was on with a man to whom she had been introduced by friends.

title: Was It Me? Or My Teeth?
description: This essay is part of a collaborative project with Black History, Continued. We invited readers and renowned writers to respond to the question What is Black love today?

title: Our Bond Was Thicker Than Blood
description: This essay is part of a collaborative project with Black History, Continued. We invited readers and renowned writers to respond to the question What is Black love today?

title: Two Boys on Bicycles, Falling in Love
description: This essay is part of a collaborative project with Black History, Continued. We invited readers and renowned writers to respond to the question What is Black love today?

title: She Wouldnt Break Her Heart to Mend Mine
description: This essay is part of a collaborative project with Black History, Continued. We invited readers and renowned writers to respond to the question What is Black love today?

title: Accepting Applications for a Black Boyfriend
description: This essay is part of a collaborative project with Black History, Continued. We invited readers and renowned writers to respond to the question What is Black love today?

title: Love Isnt a Zero-Sum Game
description: This essay is part of a collaborative project with Black History, Continued. We invited readers and renowned writers to respond to the question What is Black love today?

title: What Is Black Love Today?
description: When we invited readers  as well as renowned writers such as Staceyann Chin, Mahogany Browne and Damon Young  to respond to the question What is Black love today? we were moved by the strength, resilience and diversity of the stories they told us.

title: Beyond Cool, She Was Fly. Her Confidence Gave Me Wings.
description: This essay is part of a collaborative project with Black History, Continued. We invited readers and renowned writers to respond to the question What is Black love today?

title: What Elon Musk Did and Didnt Reveal About SpaceXs Starship Rocket
description: On an outdoor stage in South Texas between screens with polished computer animations and a real gigantic shiny rocket behind him, Elon Musk provided his latest update on his dreams to send people to settle Mars on Thursday evening.

title: Quotation of the Day: With Buildup on Land and Sea, Russia Closes Noose on Ukraine
description: I am honestly disappointed that were having the conversation of a mute person with a deaf person. Its as though we are hearing each other, but not listening.

title: Corrections: Feb. 11, 2022
description: An article on Thursday about a clash in Syria at a detention camp for family members of Islamic State fighters described incorrectly the nature of a shooting there. It was the first time that guards had fatally shot a child at the camp, according to aid workers, not the first time that guards had fired on children there.

title: The Lesbian Writer and Her Flamboyant Gay Husband
description: This essay is part of a collaborative project with Black History, Continued. We invited readers and renowned writers to respond to the question What is Black love today?

title: U.S. overnight broadcast coverage includes skeleton and hockey.
description: The U.S. broadcast coverage of the 2022 Winter Games continues on Friday. All times are Eastern.

title: 12 Economically Insecure Americans on What Keeps Them Up at Night
description: As politicians panic about inflation and the national debt, the people they represent have more immediate concerns on their minds. Their grocery stores are running out of chicken. Their electric bills are tripling month over month. And they sometimes have to trek clear across town, 45 minutes, just to find a pack of toilet paper they can afford.

title: Deadline Day for Unvaccinated Municipal Employees in N.Y.C.
description: Good morning. Its Friday. Well look at why 3,000 New York City workers could be fired today and how a Long Island Republican used a mask rebellion to revive his career. Well also meet the new president of Jesuit-run Fordham University, a laywoman, not a Catholic priest.

title: In-Betweens: 2 Middle Grade Novels About the Costs and Benefits of Being 11
description: ANYBODY HERE SEEN FRENCHIE?By Leslie Connor

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: The Kremlin is tightening its military vise on Ukraine, as thousands of Russian troops yesterday began 10 days of exercises in Belarus. Ukraine also warned of upcoming Russian naval drills so extensive that they would block shipping lanes. Aside from Belarus, satellite images revealed deployments of Russian military equipment and troops in Crimea and western Russia.

title: A speedskating rivalry between the Netherlands and Sweden heats up in Beijing.
Fast Sleds, Black Women and Two Decades of Medals
description: See our coverage of the closing ceremony of the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics here.

title: The U.S. womens hockey team survives a scare and advances to a semifinal.
description: The American womens hockey team is one win from playing for another gold medal, but only after it endured a decidedly unnerving outing on Friday in Beijing.

title: No Hijabs for Now, Indian Court Tells Muslim Students
description: UDUPI, India  An Indian court has said that students in the southern state of Karnataka should stop wearing religious garments in class until it makes a final ruling on whether a school there can ban Muslim head scarves, an issue that has stoked weeks of protests and violence and led the authorities to close schools across the state.

title: No shirt, no problem: How American Samoas flag-bearer lit up the internet.
description: YANQING, China  Nathan Ikon Crumpton, a skeleton athlete at the Winter Olympics, woke up in Beijing last weekend as a new sports hero in China  and he hadnt even competed yet.

title: Word of the Day: gamut
description: The word gamut has appeared in 94 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 28 in How an 11-Foot-Tall 3-D Printer Is Helping to Create a Community by Debra Kamin:

title: As Other Hot Spots Boil, U.S. Shows Its Foreign Policy Focus Is Asia
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  With Europe bracing for the possibility of its biggest ground war in decades, the American secretary of state, Antony J. Blinken, took a 27-hour flight this week in the opposite direction.

title: Read the document
description: The statement issued Thursday by the Karnataka High Court in Bangalore, the state capital.

title: An Olympians Routine: Skiing, Shooting, Soldiering
description: JERICHO, Vt.  Sean Doherty, an American biathlete, has been prepping for the Beijing Olympics by training, getting ample rest and keeping an especially close eye on Russian military affairs.

title: Readers Reflect on the State of Australian Politics
description: In last weeks Australia Letter, Besha Rodell wrote about her frustrations with the current state of Australias politics. She invited readers to send in their own feelings on the matter. Here are some excerpts from the many responses we got:

title: Id do anything for a medal, but I wont do that.
description: Ask big air snowboarders, downhill racers, freeskiing aerialists and lugers which other events they find scary, and they all give the same answer: Practically all of them. It was a line of questioning put to about 40 Winter Olympic athletes who do dangerous feats, part of a Times project on fear for the Beijing Games.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: FRIDAY  Hi busy bees! Welcome to todays Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: Bigbug Review: Rise of the Machines
description: In Jean-Pierre Jeunets futuristic farce, Bigbug, a suite of loyal domestic robots moves to protect a suburban family from bigger, badder androids. As the film progresses, though, it becomes clear that these particular humans might not be worth saving.

title: The In Between Review: Love Never Dies
description: Like its foremother, Twilight, The In Between depicts a pedantic girl in a supernatural world whos willing to die for her boyfriend. But where the Twilight films at least culminated in a decapitation or two, this feature, from the director Arie Posin and the Serendipity screenwriter Marc Klein, focuses solely on its fatal romance.

title: Spurning Demand by the Taliban, Biden Moves to Split $7 Billion in Frozen Afghan Funds
Australia Declares Koalas an Endangered Species
description: SYDNEY, Australia  The Australian government on Friday declared the koala an endangered species, as drought, bush fires, disease and habitat loss have drastically reduced the numbers of an animal that is an emblem of the countrys unique wildlife.

title: See How Ayumu Hirano Made Olympic History in Halfpipe to Win Gold
description: Ayumu Hirano of Japan was the first to land a triple cork in the Olympics on his way to capturing the gold medal and beating a deep field of medal contenders that included Shaun White.

title: New in Paperback: The Vanishing Half and Tangled Up in Blue
description: THE VANISHING HALF, by Brit Bennett. (Riverhead, 400 pp., $18.) Bennetts novel, one of the Book Reviews 10 Best Books of 2020, follows the diverging lives of two mixed-race women from Louisiana as they try to find their footing in America during the late 20th century. Our reviewer, Ayana Mathis, called it a brave foray into vast and difficult terrain that raises thorny questions about the cost of blackness.

title: 6 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Selections from the current Weekend section, including a brief history of hip-hop and the Super Bowl halftime show.

title: Julie Otsuka Dives Into the Underground World of the Community Pool
description: THE SWIMMERS By Julie Otsuka

title: Hes a Transgender Archivist and a Vampire, and Hes in Love
description: DEAD COLLECTIONSBy Isaac Fellman

title: True Love?
description: Valentines Day is fast approaching. For many, its a day to celebrate with a special someone. What plans, if any, do you have for Valentines Day?

title: Love-Bombing. Gaslighting. Victim. Is Trauma Talk Overused?
description: When talking to your friends, or scrolling through TikTok or Instagram, do you often use or hear words like trauma, gaslighting, love-bombing, or victim to describe everyday experiences and behaviors?

title: Lesson of the Day: 5 Things You Might Not Know About Truckers
description: This lesson is a part of our Accessible Activities feature, which aims to welcome a wider variety of learners to our site and to The Times. Learn more and tell us what you think here.

title: Its Not Your Fault You Cant Pay Attention. Heres Why.
description: The sensation of being alive in the early 21st century consisted of the sense that our ability to pay attention  to focus  was cracking and breaking, writes Johann Hari in his new book, Stolen Focus. Later he says, It felt like our civilization had been covered with itching powder and we spent our time twitching and twerking our minds, unable to simply give attention to things that matter.

title: A Mexican Jewelry Maker Who Channels 90s Nostalgia
description: Name: Sofia Elias

title: The New York Times News Quiz, February 11, 2022
description: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

title: My Husband and I Dont Speak the Same Love Language
description: I hadnt heard about the love languages until it was too late, until I was married to someone who didnt speak mine.

title: Lakers Pass Trade Deadline Unchanged and Uncertain
description: The Los Angeles Lakers were not in a great place ahead of the N.B.A. trade deadline on Thursday. They had disgruntled stars, a losing record and a general air of dysfunction a couple of months before the playoffs were scheduled to start.

title: They Took a Chance on Collaborative Living. They Lost Everything.
description: For Claudia Ruffle, living in a co-housing community was a lifelong dream. She longed for connection with people who shared her values, particularly around concern for the environment. But as an introvert, she found it hard to meet people on her own.

title: In Team Pursuit, U.S. Hopes to Push Their Way to Victory
Americas Russia Policy Has a Biden Problem
description: There are many things the Biden administration has done right in managing the crisis Russia provoked over Ukraine.

title: The Supreme Court Is Just Doing What the Supreme Court Does
description: Under a traditionally liberal view of the Supreme Court, its decision on Monday to uphold, at least for this year, a congressional map in Alabama that intentionally weakens the voting strength of Black people in the state is a betrayal of its duty to protect the rights of minorities, racial and otherwise.

title: They Criticized the N.Y.P.D. It Cost Them Their Jobs.
description: In the shadow of the Verrazzano-Narrows Bridge, Fontbonne Hall Academy in Brooklyn has not been hit by the forces of cultural change quite as bluntly as so many other private schools, which have spent the past few years embracing increasingly progressive values. Founded in 1937 by the Congregation of the Sisters of St. Joseph, an order devoted to the goal of fostering love, unity and reconciliation, the girls school professes a commitment to restorative justice. But when it had the opportunity to put that principle into practice last week, it chose a less forgiving path.

title: In Search of the Meaning of Life? Meet Me at the Monkey Bars.
description: Julian Shapiro-Barnum brims with creative energy, often scribbling ideas for new projects in his Moleskine the way others might add items to a shopping list. And though he graduated in 2021 from the B.F.A. acting program at Boston University, he said hes never wanted fame.

title: When Ski Ballet Pushed at the Porous Boundary Between Art and Sport
description: Recently, the official Olympics YouTube account posted a video both beautiful and strange. Skiers in flamboyant jumpsuits perform choreographed routines to music  flipping over their poles, gliding through complex spins, accenting transitions with jazzy flourishes of their arms. HOW was this an Olympic sport? the videos title wonders.

title: The Center That Shaped Black Life in 1970s Brooklyn
description: At 10 Claver Place, sandwiched between a 24-hour parking garage and a beige apartment building, stands a three-story complex that was once the epicenter of Pan-Africanism in Brooklyn.

title: Tracing the Troubled Path of a Man Accused of Murder
description: When a big, awful front-page crime happens, a reporters job is pretty straightforward: answer the basic questions of who, what, when, how and, if possible, why.

title: Why an Arizona County Turned Down $1.9 Million in Covid Relief
description: The $1.9 million in pandemic aid would have gone a long way in Cochise County, a rural borderland where a winter of infections swamped hospitals. There was money for tracking cases. Testing in remote ranching towns. Funds fortifying the Arizona countys strained health department.

title: Keeping an Eye on the Middle
description: After an initial downturn at the beginning of the pandemic, the housing market in the New York region has seen price gains in the double digits on co-ops, condos and houses in the last couple of years.

title: Shining a Spotlight on the Art of Translation
description: When Jennifer Croft talks about translating the Polish novelist Olga Tokarczuks novel Flights, she sometimes affectionately refers to the book as our love child.

title: Once a Threat to the Season, Omicron Is Sitting Out the Super Bowl
description: [Read how the Los Angeles Rams won the Super Bowl.]

title: How a Model and Fashion Entrepreneur Spends Her Sundays
description: Its a busy time of year for the model Lauren Chan, with the flurry of activity surrounding New York Fashion Week Friday through Wednesday. Her runway gigs will include 11 Honor, Christian Siriano and Peter Do, which she will fit in around running her company, Henning, a size-inclusive womens clothing line, for which she also designs.

title: Will Rapid Grocery Delivery Change N.Y.C.? Look to Berlin.
description: When he moved to a new apartment last fall, Garret MacAllen needed garbage bags, so he placed his first order through Gorillas, a rapid delivery service that had just arrived in New York. Since then, he has grown more reliant on the app, which promises groceries in minutes, delivering corner-store basics like milk and eggs alongside specialty items like gourmet frozen pizzas and artisanal chocolates.

title: The Last Pandemic Aid Anybody Wants to Need
description: Maybe it was because Kerri Raissians father had spent time in two hospitals and a nursing facility during the last 12 days of his life. Or maybe it was because he had been in the emergency room for only a few hours before he died. Either way, Covid-19 was not listed on his death certificate.

title: I Used Apple AirTags, Tiles and a GPS Tracker to Watch My Husbands Every Move
description: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: New York could fire as many as 3,000 unvaccinated city workers on Friday.
description: New York City on Friday is expected to fire as many as 3,000 municipal workers who have refused to get coronavirus vaccines.

title: In the Jewish Tradition, the Words We Choose Matter
description: The Torah begins with the world being created by words. Let there be is the recurring refrain. God names each item  Light. Day. Night. Darkness. Earth. Sea. Heaven. From this emerges the concept that words can build or destroy.

title: Van der Poel breaks the world record in the mens 10,000-meter speedskating.
description: Nils van der Poel broke his own world record Friday night en route to winning the mens 10,000-meter speedskating race and picking up his second gold medal of the Beijing Olympics.

title: The Saga of Joe Rogan
description: Joe Rogan, a comedian and host of the hit podcast, The Joe Rogan Experience, has come under scrutiny in recent weeks for promoting Covid-19 misinformation. Spotify, which owns exclusive rights to Mr. Rogans show, has been criticized as the platform for the misinformation.

title: Follow the Science?
description: The C.D.C. describes medium-rare hamburgers as undercooked and dangerous. The agency also directs Americans to avoid raw cookie dough and not to eat more than a teaspoon or so of salt every day. And the C.D.C. tells sexually active women of childbearing age not to drink alcohol unless they are on birth control.

title: An Arizona county turned down $1.9 million in Covid relief. This is why.
description: The $1.9 million in pandemic aid would have gone a long way in Cochise County, Ariz., a rural borderland where a winter of infections swamped hospitals. There was money for tracking cases. Testing in remote ranching towns. Funds fortifying the countys strained health department.

title: The Morning: The wishful thinking behind follow the science.
description: In Fridays edition of the Morning newsletter, David Leonhardt writes:

title: Finding Comfort in Trials and Triumphs Past
description: Next month, the Covid-19 pandemic enters its third year. Many of us thought that by now wed be looking at the virus in retrospect, instead of living in a kind of perpetually deferred future tense.

title: In Mexico, Ornately Painted Churches Enshrine Years of Indigenous Resilience
description: FOR CENTURIES, THE first thing that residents of the Mexican village of Nurio saw when they walked through the heavy wooden doors of their adobe-plastered church was an orchestra of angels. Painted on pine panels mounted in an arch beneath the choir, the images were likely completed in the mid-1600s, less than 150 years after the first Franciscan missionaries arrived here in the Meseta Purpecha, or Tarascan Plateau, a highland region in the Michoacn state named for the Indigenous community that resides there. Set in pearlescent medallions against a blue-green field coiled with gold and crimson filigree, the angels held harps, guitars and violins in their hands, their Baroque lips curved into smiles  an image of heaven filled with music, order and joy.

title: The trucker blockade is starting to take an economic toll.
description: Blockades of border crossings between the United States and Canada have disrupted production for some automakers and their suppliers, causing workers to be sent home.

title: Omicron stalled Britains economic recovery in December.
description: The sudden emergence of the fast-spreading Omicron variant of the coronavirus in Britain late last year stalled the countrys economic recovery, data confirmed on Friday, though the impact was milder than expected.

title: Why Are Russians in Beijing if Russia Is Banned for Doping?
description: BEIJING  The figure skating competition at the 2022 Beijing Olympics was thrown into turmoil on Friday with the revelation that Kamila Valieva, the 15-year-old star of the Russian team and a favorite to win two golds, had tested positive for a banned substance during a competition before the Games.

title: To Lure Back Audiences, Spoleto Festival Plans an Ambitious Season
description: After two years of disruptions brought on by the coronavirus, Spoleto Festival USA, the renowned arts group in Charleston, S.C, announced on Friday an ambitious season that it hopes will bring audiences back to live performances.

title: A Staple of Grandmas Medicine Cabinet Gets Hot on TikTok
description: The Flaming Lips claimed it could be used as a spread on toast in their 1993 hit song She Dont Use Jelly.

title: The Auto Industrys Trucker Problem
description: Thousands of truckers in Canada, protesting vaccine mandates and other restrictions, have blocked traffic at a number of key border crossings with the U.S. in the past few days. This has clogged some of the auto industrys main routes to get car parts into and out of the U.S. The Ambassador Bridge, which connects Windsor and Detroit, carries roughly a quarter of the trade between Canada and the U.S., and a third of the cargo that uses the bridge is related to the auto industry.

title: A Pandemic Puppy Changed the Way I See (and Hear and Smell) My World
description: About half a mile from my house, a red knit scarf has been wrapped around a telephone pole for almost two years. Dont ask me why its there, but almost every day I pay it a visit with my dog, Bowie. Fortunately for him, the scarf, faded to a sad shade of pink, has slipped far enough down the pole that he can now give it a proper sniff.

title: Top job vacancies may hurt Bidens research agenda, which extends well beyond fighting the pandemic.
description: President Biden, who came into office vowing to reinvigorate our national science and technology strategy, is now facing a leadership vacuum that may threaten his ambitious research agenda, which stretches well beyond fighting the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Whats black and white, weighs half a pound and is popular in China?
description: Nobody expected a shortage of stuffed pandas when China won the rights to host the 2022 Winter Olympics. But a week into the Games, the Chinese public now appears interested in little else.

title: What to Know About the Super Bowl
description: The Super Bowl is never just a football game. But the nations biggest annual sporting event, which is set to take place on Sunday at the futuristic SoFi Stadium in Inglewood, has taken on extra significance this year.

title: A broadcasters lineup creates a halfpipe cliffhanger in Japan.
description: It was Ayumu Hiranos last ride, and the final run of the mens halfpipe finals at the Beijing Olympics on Friday. Shaun White, the American snowboarder competing in his last Olympic Games, had already fallen, leaving a spot for his successor on the top step of the medals podium.

title: The Lox Story: From Scandinavia to New York
description: This is Clued In, a column that will give you insight into some of the New York Times Crossword clues and answers.

title: Dance, I Said  Dance! And Leave the Package on the Porch.
description: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: Dont Expect Higher Savings Rates Anytime Soon
description: Interest rates are likely to begin rising this year, and that should be good news for savers  right?

title: Switzerland, Long a Safe Haven for Tobacco Ads, Weighs a Ban
description: ZURICH  The images are jarring to visitors: happy, glamorous couples smoking together in a cafe, packs of cigarettes opened invitingly, rugged Western landscapes that evoke the Marlboro Man.

title: For Three Avant-Garde Musicians, Its Time for Pop
description: In his recent documentary about the Velvet Underground, Todd Haynes depicted both poles of that groups creativity. There were moments featuring collaborations with experimental composers like La Monte Young and Tony Conrad, but also passages of fairly pure pop bliss.

title: White House Warns Russian Invasion of Ukraine Could Happen at Any Time
description: Read our latest coverage of the Ukraine crisis.

title: In Severance, Adam Scott Gets to Work
description: Severance, an unnerving workplace drama, was originally scheduled to begin filming in March 2020, but pandemic shutdowns pushed the shoot to the fall. So in October 2020, Adam Scott, the shows star, left his family in Los Angeles and flew to New York.

title: Jazz Freed Keith LaMars Soul. Can It Help Him Get Off Death Row?
description: Keith LaMar has spent 33 years in prison, nearly all of it in solitary confinement. He is scheduled to be executed in Ohio next year, after being convicted in the 1993 killing of five fellow inmates during a prison riot.

title: Taliban Free 2 Westerners Working for U.N., Days After Quiet Detention
description: ISTANBUL  The Taliban on Friday released two Western citizens and two Afghan colleagues who had been working for the United Nations in Afghanistan, hours after the U.N. had announced that they had been held by the Taliban for several days in Afghanistan.

title: The Weekender
description: The magic of birdwatching. Also in this edition: an Amelia Earhart mystery is solved, and how The Sims became the internets most exciting place to eat.

title: Revenge Is a Dish Best Served Out of the Office
description: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

title: Stolen Buddha Statue That Resurfaced in Italy Will Return to India
description: Indian officials have received a Buddha statue that had gone missing more than two decades ago from its altar at one of the countrys most important Buddhist pilgrimage sites, the Devisthan Kundalpur Temple in Bihar.

title: Omicron, once a threat to the N.F.L. season, may largely spare the Super Bowl.
description: Less than two months ago, the Los Angeles Rams were going through what the quarterback Matthew Stafford called that tough couple weeks. As the Omicron variant of the coronavirus swept across the country, more than 30 Rams players tested positive during the last three weeks of December. At one point, nearly all of them, including seven starters, were on the reserve/Covid-19 list at the same time.

title: Prepare Yourself for This Weekends Crypto Bowl
description: [Read how the Los Angeles Rams won the Super Bowl.]

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Good morning. Eric Kim is in The Times this week with an argument for cooking together on Valentines Day and a menu to follow: seared radicchio with melty cheese; individual beef Wellingtons (above); and no-churn olive oil ice cream with hot fudge.

title: Love or Hate Valentines Day? Either Way, There Are Movies for You.
description: Depending on how you feel about Valentines Day, these streaming picks will either melt or break your heart.

title: Shredded, Flushed or Removed: The Trump Papers
description: To the Editor:

title: Lets Play Recipe Matchmaker
description: Are you looking for your dream pasta? Tanya Sichynsky, a senior staff editor at New York Times Food and Cooking, has some recommendations.

title: U.S. intelligence says Putin has accelerated his timetable and could invade within days.
description: The U.S. intelligence community has told the White House and American allies that there are signs that President Vladimir V. Putin has moved up his timetable and could launch an invasion of Ukraine within days, according three Western officials briefed on the discussions.

title: Wonking Out: Very Serious Folk Economics
description: A few days ago, Tressie McMillan Cottom published an insightful article in The Times about the power of folk economics  which she defined as the very human impulse to describe complex economic processes in lay terms. Her subject was the widespread enthusiasm for cryptocurrency, but her article sent me down memory lane, recalling the role folk economics has played in past policy debates.

title: 7 Simple Exercises To Strengthen Your Relationship
description: Try these science-based ideas for forging a deeper connection with someone you love.

title: An Olympian from Ukraine protests over war during his skeleton competition.
description: A Ukrainian athlete displayed a no war in Ukraine sign after finishing a run in the mens skeleton competition on Friday.

title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
description: Stream it on Ovid or on Criterion Channel.

title: Bob Wall, Martial Arts Master Who Sparred With Bruce Lee, Dies at 82
description: Bob Wall, a martial arts master who with quick business wits and even fleeter fists helped propel disciplines like karate, aikido and Brazilian jiu-jitsu into the American mainstream, along the way making friends and sharing the screen with the likes of Bruce Lee and Chuck Norris, died on Jan. 30 in Los Angeles. He was 82.

title: Border Blockades Keep Auto Production and Trade Off Kilter
description: Blockades of the U.S.-Canada border stymied flows of critical supplies for the fourth day on Friday, leaving companies scrambling for materials and shutting down major auto factories from Ontario to Alabama.

title: A One-Pot Short Rib Stew Thats Brimming With Memories
description: If you need a little extra warmth this winter, let eintopf be your go-to.

title: A Shape-Shifting Opera Singer, With a Debut to Match
description: BERLIN  You might know her as the world-famous diva Emilia Marty. Or as Ellian MacGregor  maybe even Eugenia Montez or Elsa Mller. Its an open question in Janaceks operatic thriller The Makropulos Case, about the twilight of a woman who has adopted an assortment of identities throughout her unnaturally long life.

title: Refresh Your Sweet Potatoes With Fried Eggs
description: The only complaint my husband, Daniel, has about my cooking is that every time I make something he loves, I never cook it again.

title: Why a Kanye West Documentary Took Two Decades to See the Light
description: Jeen-yuhs: A Kanye Trilogy, Netflixs three-part documentary about the rise of Kanye West, does not dwell, or seek to correct the record, on the most well-known of the rappers celebrity blowups. George W. Bush, Taylor Swift, Donald Trump and Kim Kardashian hardly factor. There has never been a shortage of West analyzing his own travails, after all.

title: University of Alabama Removes Klan Leaders Name From Building
description: The trustees of the University of Alabama on Friday reversed a decision to name a building after both a Ku Klux Klan leader and the first Black person to attend the school, instead voting to solely honor the student, Autherine Lucy Foster.

title: Medina Spirit May Have Died of a Heart Attack, a Necropsy Finds
description: Medina Spirit, the race horse whose victory in the 2021 Kentucky Derby had been called into question by a failed post-race drug test, may have died of a heart attack but a necropsy report was inconclusive, according to California regulators on Friday. Hair, blood and urine samples showed no evidence of doping.

title: How Does Cooper Kupp Always Get the Ball?
description: [Read how the Los Angeles Rams won the Super Bowl.]

title: Richard Christiansen, Influential Chicago Theater Critic, Dies at 90
description: In 1970, as Americans were preparing to mark the first Earth Day, Richard Christiansen, still relatively early in what would become a storied career of writing about theater in Chicago, seized the moment to argue that the arts deserved just as much attention as the environment but were unlikely to receive it.

title: Forget Chocolate Bars: Baking With Chips Is Often Better
description: It took two months for Claudia Martnez, the executive pastry chef at Miller Union in Atlanta, to perfect her salted chocolate-chip cookie recipe. For the morsels, she ended up using a high-end chocolate  Lacte Barry Equilibre from the French chocolate company Cacao Barry  and was happy with her results. But when she tried some cookies that her regulars had made for her as gifts, she thought they tasted way better than her own.

title: Taylor Swift and Ed Sheeran Up the Ante, and 13 More New Songs
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

title: Inspired by Canadian protests, thousands of French demonstrators converge on Paris.
description: Thousands of vehicles carrying demonstrators from around France were converging on Paris on Friday in a movement inspired by Canadas trucker-led protests, despite warnings by French authorities that they would break up attempts to block the capital.

title: How a Chechen Abduction Exposes Putins Problems at Home
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is flexing his military and diplomatic muscle in a tense standoff with the West over Ukraine, projecting power and occasional menace in his pursuit of global influence. But the recent abduction of a 52-year-old diabetic woman in central Russia  has made clear that Mr. Putin still has vexing challenges in his own backyard that require a skillful political juggling act.

title: A Brooklyn private school backtracks on its plan to make masks optional, in deference to state mandate.
description: Poly Prep Country Day School, an elite, expensive Brooklyn institution, will continue to require students and staff to wear masks in school, reversing a decision to make masks optional starting Monday.

title: Marry Me | Anatomy of a Scene
description: The director Kat Coiro narrates a sequence from her film featuring Jennifer Lopez, Owen Wilson and Maluma.

title: Watch Jennifer Lopez Perform in Marry Me
description: In Anatomy of a Scene, we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

title: On the Scene: Music Man, a Big Broadway Bet
description: The Music Man, a big-budget, star-studded musical, opened Thursday, hoping to provide Broadway with a much-needed boost.

title: James Webb Telescope Sends Home a Selfie and 18 Images of Starlight
description: Two months after a dramatic Christmas morning launch and several spine-tingling weeks of gyrations and unfoldings, the James Webb Space Telescope has achieved what astronomers celebrate as first light.

title: How to Organize Your Digital Files
description: Find what you're looking for faster.

title: She Had Never Acted, and Could Barely Read. Now, Shes an Egyptian Movie Star.
description: AL BARSHA, Egypt  When the star of Feathers, the most talked about  and critically acclaimed  Egyptian movie of the past year, showed up to shoot her first scenes, she had never acted before. She could not even read her lines.

title: What is trimetazidine? Would it have helped Kamila Valieva of Russia?
description: Update: Kamila Valievas sample had three substances sometimes used to help the heart.

title: The F.D.A. delays action on Covid shots for young children.
description: WASHINGTON  In a striking reversal, federal regulators said on Friday that they would wait for data on whether three doses of Pfizer-BioNTechs coronavirus vaccine are effective in children younger than 5 before deciding whether to authorize a vaccine for the age group.

title: Its Time to Answer Your Questions About Super Bowl LVI
description: Answering questions you know are crucial for Sunday, and some ones we know youre secretly thinking about.

title: Weeknights Are for Lovers
description: I sort of love Valentines Day, which is coming up on Monday, and which I acknowledge is a little ridiculous as a day on the calendar. But I find its retro sweetness irresistible, especially when its done right, with French toast, strong cocktails, fudgy desserts and homemade Valentines.

title: More Brew and Less Buzz, With Low-Alcohol Beers
description: One summer day in 2018, Sean Boisson was washing his car in Sonoma, Calif., when a bubbly little epiphany arrived. He asked his younger sister, Brittany Rossi, who was helping, if she wanted a second beer  a domestic lager low in alcohol, but not quite low enough. She was like: No, Ive got to drive. I can only have one, Mr. Boisson recalled.

title: Love Letter: What is Black Love Today?
description: Last August, Modern Love and The New York Timess Narrative Projects team invited readers and a few prominent writers to respond to the question: What is Black love today?

title: A Dance to the Music of Time and T.S. Eliot
description: In its beginning is its end. In its end is its beginning. Those tail-eating lines, paraphrased from Four Quartets, the poem by T.S. Eliot, tell you the outer shape of Four Quartets, the much-acclaimed dance by Pam Tanowitz that had its New York City debut at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Thursday.

title: The New N-Word Standard Isnt Progress
description: Over roughly the past two decades, American mores have been settling into an idea that when it comes to the N-word, theres no difference between use (lobbing the word as a slur in reference to a Black person or Black people) and mention (referring to the word itself). Particularly if the speaker is white.

title: People Hate Inflation. But We Need to Keep Higher Prices in Perspective.
description: After Thursdays report that consumer prices rose over the past year by the most since 1982, the Federal Reserve is under pressure to squelch inflation by raising interest rates. But if the Fed acts too aggressively, it could cause a recession and throw people out of work. And lets face it, being unemployed is worse than paying more for stuff.

title: Queen Lucy Was a Basketball Superstar. How Will We Remember Her?
description: The daughter of sharecroppers. The only Black basketball player on a college team she led to three national championships. The first woman to score a basket at the Olympics. So good she was the first (and only) woman officially drafted by the National Basketball Association.

title: Inflation May Have Already Peaked. The Fed Needs to Step Gingerly.
description: The headlines have been alarming.

title: The Nets Were to Be a Team of Destiny. But Not This Kind.
description: WASHINGTON  Nets Coach Steve Nash gave a pained smile in the barren hallway leading to the court at Capital One Arena. The Nets were in the middle of an implosion, having lost nine straight games, soon to be 10. He was asked about his unequivocal statement just days before that James Harden, the Nets All-Star guard, wouldnt be traded.

title: Whether Hes Talking Amlie or Bigbug, Jean-Pierre Jeunet Doesnt Hold Back
description: The French director Jean-Pierre Jeunet is a conjurer of whimsical visions for the big screen, like his most beloved work, Amlie. But for his first movie in nearly a decade, Bigbug, out Friday, he chose to work with Netflix.

title: Douglas Trumbull, Visual Effects Wizard, Dies at 79
description: Douglas Trumbull, an audacious visual effects wizard who created memorable moments in a series of blockbuster science-fiction films, including the hallucinogenic sequence in Stanley Kubricks 2001: A Space Odyssey in which an astronaut in a pod hurtles through space, died on Feb. 7 at a hospital in Albany, N.Y. He was 79.

title: How a Tawdry Steakhouse Melee Transfixed Miami Politics
description: CORAL GABLES, Fla.  Every so often, a petty political episode consumes Miami, its piquant details transfixing the city for days. Like the one that began this week at Mortons Steakhouse during a late lunch, when a lobbyist happened upon a city commissioner.

title: The Pentagon is sending 3,000 more troops to Poland.
description: The Pentagon on Friday ordered 3,000 additional troops to Poland, bringing to 5,000 the total number of reinforcements sent to Europe in the past two weeks.

title: Mifunes Transcendent Films, With and Without Kurosawa
description: Toshiro Mifune once wrote of his collaboration with the director Akira Kurosawa, I have never as an actor done anything that I am proud of other than with him.

title: In Fourth Title Defense, Israel Adesanya Will Face a Familiar Foe
description: A diamond stud glittered in Israel Adesanyas left ear, while the right sleeve on his beige suede jacket rode up to expose a gleaming gold watch. The timepiece matched the shiny plates on the front of the black leather title belt that Adesanya had placed on the dais for the fight week news conference.

title: Remembering What Draws You In
description: Astead Herndon, who follows politics for The Times and Tottenham Hotspur because he just cant help himself, is filling in for Rory Smith this week.

title: Failed Test Casts Shadow Over Skating, the Olympics Showcase Event
description: Update: Kamila Valievas sample had three substances sometimes used to help the heart.

title: Mayor Adams says the rush of last-minute vaccinations by New York City workers is an encouraging sign.
description: With thousands of New York City workers facing a deadline to get vaccinated or lose their jobs, Mayor Eric Adams said on Friday that he was encouraged by the rush of workers getting vaccinated at the last minute.

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Johann Hari
description: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like todays episode with Johann Hari. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

title: To Frustration of Many, Trudeau Has Moved Slowly With Canada Protests
description: With the turmoil in Canada only intensifying from a protest movement that has shut down the urban cores of several cities and blocked crucial highways into the United States, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has mostly sought a quiet path through the tumult.

title: Does Magic Underwear Exist?
description: Welcome to the booming world of shapewear, a.k.a. the modern no-more-pain version of what used to be known as a girdle: stretchy undergarments that promise to suck in and hold up the parts you want sucked in and held up, polish your overall lines and otherwise create the illusion of a sculpted form.

title: Slate, the Pioneering Web Magazine, Struggles to Find Identity and Profit
description: In early January, two days after an abrupt announcement that the top editor of Slate was stepping down, the publications staff signed into a Zoom meeting with the companys chief executive and a consultant for Graham Holdings, the publication's owner.

title: Vintage Valentines Day Wishes
description: In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, the daily paper and the Book Review brimmed with ads for Valentines Day cards.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: How to Live with Covid
description: As the Omicron wave subsides in regions across the world, more governments, politicians and health officials are telling us its time to start living with the virus.

title: We Need to Talk About Cosby and Therapy for Eco-Anxiety: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

title: A Spiritual, Dangerous Quest in the Himalayas
description: Harley Rustads new book, Lost in the Valley of Death, is about an American adventurer named Justin Alexander Shetler, who went on a quest in the Himalayas that ended in his disappearance. One of Shetlers heroes was Christopher McCandless, whose story was told in Jon Krakauers Into the Wild. On this weeks podcast, Rustad discusses Shetlers life, including his use of social media and how that dovetailed  and didnt  with his spiritual journey.

title: 4 Songs That Taught Us About Love
description: I host the Modern Love podcast, and to kick off our new season, I asked my team: Whats the song that taught you about love when you were a teen?

title: F.D.A. Clears Covid Drug From Eli Lilly That Shows Promise Against Omicron
description: With Covid treatments still in short supply in the United States, the Food and Drug Administration on Friday gave emergency authorization to a new monoclonal antibody drug that has been found in the laboratory to be potent against the Omicron variant of the coronavirus.

title: On Capitol Hill, a Push to Unionize House Aides Gains Traction
description: WASHINGTON  More than 25 years after Congress first voted to give its employees the right to unionize, Democrats are making a fresh push to make it possible for House aides to bargain collectively, an uphill effort that has exposed the often difficult realities of working on Capitol Hill.

title: Ukraine, Trucker Protests, Super Bowl: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Bob Sagets Autopsy Report Describes Severe Skull Fractures
description: Bob Saget, the comedian and actor, died after what appeared to be a significant blow to the head, one that fractured his skull in several places and caused bleeding across both sides of his brain, according to an autopsy report released on Friday.

title: Canada Toughens Stance on Protests, Promising Robust Police Response
description: OTTAWA  After weeks of treading lightly around the protests paralyzing much of Canadas economy, federal, provincial and local officials adopted a markedly tougher approach on Friday, threatening protesters with arrests and heavy fines, and obtaining a court order to halt the blockade of a major route to the United States.

title: U.S. prime-time broadcast coverage includes snowboarding, biathlon and hockey.
description: The U.S. broadcast coverage of the 2022 Winter Games continues on Friday with medal events in snowboarding, hockey and Alpine and cross-country skiing. All times are Eastern.

title: Britain on the Brink
description: From The Daily newsletter: One big idea on the news, from the team that brings you The Daily podcast. You can sign up for the newsletter here.

title: Puzzle in Ukraine Crisis: Wheres the U.S. Ambassador?
description: WASHINGTON  It is a puzzle at the heart of the crisis over Russias threat to invade Ukraine: Why has President Biden, more than one year into his presidency, failed to name an ambassador to Kyiv?

title: The Traveling Trump Show
description: HIDALGO, Texas  Organizers of the three-day We Stand America gathering were clearly frustrated on Day Two: In an arena built to accommodate thousands of spectators, only a few hundred people had shown up.

title: Biden, a Veteran of Supreme Court Fights, Ponders His Own Historic Pick
description: WASHINGTON  President Biden is staying up late in the White House residence, poring over the biographies of four potential Supreme Court nominees and cases they have decided.

title: Lars Eighner, Who Wrote Eloquently of Being Homeless, Dies at 73
description: Lars Eighner, who vividly recounted his experiences with being homeless in Travels With Lizbeth, a book widely regarded as one of the finest memoirs of recent decades, died on Dec. 23 in Austin, Texas. He was 73.

title: Is the Metaverse Just Marketing?
description: From The Daily newsletter: One big idea on the news, from the team that brings you The Daily podcast. You can sign up for the newsletter here.

title: Scientists prepare for the next phase of learning to live with Covid.
description: As the Omicron wave subsides in regions across the world, more governments, politicians and health officials are telling us that its time to start living with the virus.

title: Judges snowboarding scores continue to fuel controversy.
description: For a brief moment on Thursday night, social media was ready to throw down in support of the snowboarder Ayumu Hirano of Japan. On his second run, Hirano became the first competitor in an Olympic Games to land a triple cork  three flips performed on a rotation while grabbing the board  as part of what the NBC analyst Todd Richards called the best run thats ever been done in the halfpipe.

title: Lia Thomas Is Cleared to Swim at N.C.A.A. Championships
description: The N.C.A.A. on Friday cleared the way for the swimmer Lia Thomas, a transgender woman who has turned in the top times in the country in two events, to compete in the N.C.A.A. championships next month, saying that implementing new rules for testosterone testing in the middle of the season would be unfair to transgender athletes.

title: Recent studies underscore the dangers of pregnancy complications for unvaccinated women with Covid.
description: Two new reports lay out the added difficulties that unvaccinated women with Covid have during pregnancy and childbirth, adding to research showing that they face elevated risks.

title: Rick Caruso, Billionaire Developer, Jumps Into Los Angeles Mayors Race
description: Rick J. Caruso, a billionaire real estate developer and longtime civic figure, jumped into the race for mayor of Los Angeles on Friday, shaking up a crowded field for the top job in the nations second-largest city after more than a decade of flirting with a run.

title: In Reversal, F.D.A. Delays Push for Shots for Children Under 5
description: WASHINGTON  In a striking reversal, federal regulators said on Friday that they would wait for data on how well three doses of Pfizer-BioNTechs coronavirus vaccine work in children younger than 5 before deciding whether to authorize the vaccine for that age group.

title: We Underestimated Putin Once. We Cant Make That Mistake Again.
description: The White House on Friday came out with its starkest warning yet on the threat facing Ukraine, saying Moscow could invade any day now. The national security adviser, Jake Sullivan, stressed there was no way to predict what President Vladimir Putin of Russia might do  but history shows we should not underestimate Mr. Putins willingness to violate another countrys sovereignty.

title: Harris Says Replacing Lead Pipes Is a Priority, Despite Limited Funding
description: NEWARK  Schkeema Troutman had just started describing the many difficulties of trying to raise a family in a city with high levels of lead in its drinking water when Vice President Kamala Harris noticed the mother of three was not being heard.

title: Where the Canadian Trucker Protests Happened
description: Truck drivers protesting vaccine mandates parked their trucks in cities across Canada, blocking traffic and disrupting the flow of goods between the nation and the U.S.

title: Golden years: Jacobellis, 36, and Baumgartner, 40, win in team snowboard cross.
description: Lindsey Jacobellis had gone 16 years in search of the Olympic gold medal that she squandered back in 2006, when she fell just before the finish line.

title: The Supreme Court rejects a bid by New York teachers to block a city vaccine mandate.
description: The Supreme Court on Friday rejected an emergency request that it consider an appeal by a group of New York City teachers seeking to block a vaccine mandate over what they said was a discriminatory religious exemption policy.

title: Trump Flouted Presidential Records Law. Will He Face Consequences?
description: WASHINGTON  While he was president, Donald J. Trump was known to destroy, tear up, remove and even flush White House documents down the toilet. He often eschewed the White House switchboard, using his own cellphone or those of his aides to communicate.

title: Turmoil in Canada Intensifies as Protests Threaten Economy
description: Despite a mass of protesters demanding an end to vaccine mandates and coronavirus restrictions in Canada, polls have shown that a majority of Canadians support the pandemic health measures.

title: A Beijing Games first: Real snow in Zhangjiakou.
description: Chinas water-scarce capital went to enormous lengths to make enough artificial snow for the Winter Olympics. But on Saturday morning, athletes in the mountains woke up to the real deal.

title: What Comes Before the Fall?
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  This is a brisk challenge from Mary Lou Guizzo, who has hit for the cycle for The New York Times, meaning that she has constructed at least one puzzle on every day of the week (as well as a bonus variety puzzle in 2016). Her themed grids are very inventive and often come with visual components, but Ill gladly work on a themeless construction like this one, which is full of interesting references and bright wordplay.

title: Cisco Has Discussed Deal for Software Company Splunk
description: Cisco Systems, the technology conglomerate, has held discussions with the software company Splunk about buying it, although no deal is currently on the table, two people familiar with the matter told The New York Times on Friday.

title: A Russian figure skaters failed test casts shadow over the Games.
description: Leaping and spinning at high speed on Monday night, Kamila Valieva of Russia became the first female figure skater to complete a quad  a jump with four rotations  at the Olympics.

title: Corrections: Feb. 12, 2022
description: Because of a production error, an article on Friday about President Bidens prediction that he would have Republican support for his Supreme Court nominee included columns of type that were out of order.

title: Quotation of the Day: Musk Boosts His Plans for Mars, but Many Hurdles Remain
description: We need to seize the opportunity and do it as quickly as possible. I want to be frank: Civilization is feeling a little fragile these days.

title: Walmart says vaccinated workers no longer have to wear masks in most states.
description: Walmart said on Friday that fully vaccinated employees would no longer have to wear masks unless state or local rules required it. The change is effective immediately, the giant retailer said in a memo to its staff.

title: U.S. overnight coverage includes ice dancing and skeleton.
description: The U.S. broadcast coverage of the 2022 Winter Games continues on Saturday. All times are Eastern.
